facts.text: A mortgage was created on August 1, 1899, by Purshottamdas in favor of Dhanrupmal for a four-roomed shop on land measuring 5 yards by 15 yards in Naya Bazar, Ajmere.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage was created by Purshottamdas who is number dead and was in favour of Dhanrupmal, a respondent in this appeal. The mortgage instrument stated that the property had been usufructuarily mortgaged in lieu of Rs. 6,300 of which Rs. 5,750 had been left with the mortgagee to redeem a prior mortgage on the same and another property.

facts.text: The mortgage amount was Rs. 6,300, of which Rs. 5,750 was left with the mortgagee to redeem a prior mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage instrument stated that the property had been usufructuarily mortgaged in lieu of Rs. 6,300 of which Rs. 5,750 had been left with the mortgagee to redeem a prior mortgage on the same and another property. It also provided that on redemption of the prior mortgage, the possession of the shop would be taken over and retained by the mortgagee, Dhanrupmal, who would appropriate its rent in lieu of interest on the money advanced by him and the possession of the other property companyered by the prior mortgage, being a share in a Kachery would be made over to the mortgagor, Purshottamdas.

facts.text: The mortgage deed provided that the mortgagor or heirs will not be entitled to redeem for 85 years, then within 6 months, or else no claim and deed deemed sale.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions in the mortgage instrument on which the present dispute turns were in these terms I or my heirs will number be entitled to redeem the property for a period of 85 years. After the expiry of 85 years we shall redeem it within a period of six months. In case we do number redeem within a period of six months, then after the expiry of the stipulated period, 1, my heirs, and legal representatives shall have numberclaim over the mortgaged property, and the mortgagee shall have numberclaim to get the mortgage money and the lagat  i. e., repairs  expenses that may be due at the time of default.

facts.text: Dhanrupmal redeemed the prior mortgage, took possession of the shop, and delivered possession of the Kacheri to Purshottamdas.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagee, Dhanrupmal, duly redeemed the earlier mortgage and, went into possession of the shop while possession of the Kacheri was delivered to the mortgagor.

facts.text: On April 12, 1939, Dhanrupmal assigned his rights under the mortgage to Motilal.

anchor.surface_text: On April 12, 1939, Dhanrupmal assigned his rights under the mortgage to Motilal who died later, and whose estate is number represented by his sons, who are the other respondents in this appeal.

facts.text: Motilal died, and his estate is represented by his sons, who are the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: On April 12, 1939, Dhanrupmal assigned his rights under the mortgage to Motilal who died later, and whose estate is number represented by his sons, who are the other respondents in this appeal. The estate of Purshottamdas, the original mortgagor, is number represented by his son, the appellant.

facts.text: Purshottamdas died, and his estate is represented by his son, the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The estate of Purshottamdas, the original mortgagor, is number represented by his son, the appellant.

facts.text: On January 2, 1947, the appellant filed suit for redemption in the Court of Sub-Judge, Ajmer, against the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: On January 2, 1947, the appellant filed the suit in the Court of the Sub-Judge, Ajmere, against the respondents. The suit was companytested by the sons of Motilal, the assignee of the mortgage, who are the only respondents appearing in this appeal and whom we shall hence, hereafter refer to as the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents contested the suit claiming it was premature as no right of redemption until August 1, 1984.

anchor.surface_text: They said that the suit was premature as under the mortgage companytract there was numberright of redemption for eighty five years after the date of the mortgage, that is to say, till August 1, 1984.

facts.text: Sub-Judge, Ajmer, on March 30, 1948, in Civil Suit No. I of 1947, held 85-year clause invalid as clog on equity of redemption and passed preliminary decree for redemption.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 21, 1950, of the Court of Judicial Commissioner at Ajmer in Civil First Appeal No. 13 of 1948, arising out of the judgment and decree dated March 30, 1948, of the Court of Sub-Judge 1st Class, Ajmer, in Civil Suit No. I of 1947.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer, on March 21, 1950, in Civil First Appeal No. 13 of 1948, reversed Sub-Judge, held no clog, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 150 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 21, 1950, of the Court of Judicial Commissioner at Ajmer in Civil First Appeal No. 13 of 1948, arising out of the judgment and decree dated March 30, 1948, of the Court of Sub-Judge 1st Class, Ajmer, in Civil Suit No. I of 1947.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court: Civil Appeal No. 150 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 150 of 1954.

facts.text: The case is governed by the Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the case is governed by the Transfer of Property Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the 6-month redemption window clause invalid as clog on equity of redemption.

anchor.surface_text: One thing, therefore, is clear, namely, that the term in the mortgage companytract, that on the failure of the mortgagor to redeem the mortgage within the specified period of six months the mortgagor will have numberclaim over the mortgaged property, and the mortgage deed will be deemed to be a deed of sale in favour of the mortgagee, cannot be sustained.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the 85-year term valid, not a clog, as no evidence of unconscionable bargain or oppression.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that the bargain was a reasonable one and the eighty-five years term of the mortgage should be enforced. We then companye to the companyclusion that the suit was premature and must fail.

facts.text: Suit for redemption brought over 47 years after mortgage (in 1947).

anchor.surface_text: The suit for redemption was brought over forty-seven years after the date of the mortgage.

facts.text: Property was subject to a prior mortgage including the shop and a share in Kacheri.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage instrument stated that the property had been usufructuarily mortgaged in lieu of Rs. 6,300 of which Rs. 5,750 had been left with the mortgagee to redeem a prior mortgage on the same and another property.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage was created by Purshottamdas who is number dead and was in favour of Dhanrupmal, a respondent in this appeal.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Sarkar J. on April 15, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Tarachand Brijmohan Lal, for the appellant. S. Deedwania and K. L. Mehta, for the respondents. 1958. April 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.

facts.text: Respondents' contention that suit brought because land prices rose after war.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Commissioner felt that the respondents companytention that the suit had been brought as the price of landed property had gone up after the war, was justified.

facts.text: Long-term mortgages are not uncommon in various parts of India.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot also ignore, as appears from a large number of reported decisions, that it is number uncommon in various parts of India to have long term mortgages.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, suit premature.

anchor.surface_text: We then companye to the companyclusion that the suit was premature and must fail.

Under s. 60 of that Act, at any time after the principal money has become due, the mortgagor has a right on payment or tender of the mortgage money to require the mortgagee to reconvey the mortgage property to him. The right conferred by this section has been called the right to redeem and the appellant sought to enforce this right by his suit. Under this section, however, that right can be exercised only after the mortgage money has become due.

concepts.interpretation: Confers the right to redeem after principal money becomes due; unqualified and cannot be limited by contract to extinguish the right once arisen.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: right on payment of the mortgage money to redeem. The section is unqualified in its terms, and companytains numbersaving provision as other sections d

concepts.unlisted_description: Mortgagor's right to redeem mortgaged property on payment of mortgage money after principal due.

Seth Swami Dayal An anomalous mortgage enabling a mortgagee after a lapse of time and in the absence of redemption to enter and take the rents in satisfaction of the interest.

concepts.interpretation: Once right to redeem arises under the section, it cannot be taken away by contract.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: right on payment of the mortgage money to redeem. The section is unqualified in its terms, and companytains numbersaving provision as other sections d

concepts.unlisted_description: Mortgagor's right to redeem mortgaged property on payment of mortgage money after principal due.

anchor.surface_text: The rule against clogs on the equity of redemption is that, a mortgage shall always be redeemable and a mortgagors right to redeem shall neither be taken away nor be limited by any contract between the parties. The principle behind the rule was expressed by Lindley M. R. in Santley v. Wilde in these words The principle is this a mortgage is a conveyance of land or an assignment of chattles as a security for the payment of a debt or the discharge of some other obligation for which it is given.

concepts.unlisted_description: Doctrine prohibiting contracts that limit or extinguish mortgagor's right to redeem.

anchor.surface_text: One thing, therefore, is clear, namely, that the term in the mortgage contract, that on the failure of the mortgagor to redeem the mortgage within the specified period of six months the mortgagor will have no claim over the mortgaged property, and the mortgage deed will be deemed to be a deed of sale in favour of the mortgagee, cannot be sustained. It plainly takes away altogether, the mortgagors right to redeem the mortgage after the specified period.

concepts.interpretation: The 6-month redemption window after 85 years, making deed a sale deed on default, is invalid as it extinguishes right to redeem.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from this, that once a mortgage always a mortgage . The right of redemption, therefore, cannot be taken away. The Courts will ignore any contract the effect of which is to deprive the mortgagor of his right to redeem the mortgage.

concepts.interpretation: Mortgage remains redeemable regardless of contractual provisions to the contrary.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ays a mortgage . The right of redemption, therefore, cannot be taken

concepts.unlisted_label: Once a Mortgage Always a Mortgage
concepts.unlisted_description: Principle that a mortgage security cannot be converted into absolute purchase.

anchor.surface_text: The reason then justifying the Courts power to relieve a mortgagor from the effects of his bargain is its want of conscience. Putting it in more familiar language the Courts jurisdiction to relieve a mortgagor from his bargain depends on whether it was obtained by taking advantage of any difficulty or embarrassment that he might have been in when he borrowed the moneys on the mortgage. Was the mortgagor oppressed ? Was he imposed upon ? If he was, then he may be entitled to relief.

concepts.interpretation: No relief where no evidence of oppression, imposition, financial embarrassment, or unfair advantage; long term reasonable given circumstances, prior mortgage redeemed partially, interest fair, common practice.

concepts.unlisted_description: Equity relieves mortgagors from unconscionable terms obtained by exploiting necessity.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the mortgage instrument permitting the mortgagee to demand any money, and it is well settled that the mortgagees right to enforce the mortgage and the mortgagors right to redeem are co-extensive.

concepts.interpretation: Mortgagee's right to enforce coincides with mortgagor's right to redeem; no unilateral demand right.

concepts.unlisted_label: Co-extensive Rights of Mortgagee and Mortgagor
concepts.unlisted_description: Mortgagee's enforcement right and mortgagor's redemption right arise simultaneously.

It plainly takes away altogether,

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 60 of that Act, at any time after the principal money has become due, the mortgagor has a right on payment or tender of the mortgage money to require the mortgagee to reconvey the mortgage property to him. The right conferred by this section has been called the right to redeem and the appellant sought to enforce this right by his suit. Under this section, however, that right can be exercised only after the mortgage money has become due.

The right conferred by this section has been called the right to redeem and the appellant sought to enforce this right by his suit.

arguments.claim: Invalidity of 6-month clause makes 85-year term invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We wish to observe here that the learned advocate did not contend that the invalidity, as we have earlier held, of the term taking away the right to redeem the mortgage after the period of six months makes the term fixing the period of the mortgage at eighty five years invalid.

arguments.court_reasoning: Stands apart; one invalidity does not affect other.

holdings.text: The term in the mortgage contract providing that on failure to redeem within six months after 85 years, the mortgagor has no claim over the property and the deed is deemed a sale deed is invalid as it constitutes a clog on the equity of redemption.

anchor.surface_text: One thing, therefore, is clear, namely, that the term in the mortgage contract, that on the failure of the mortgagor to redeem the mortgage within the specified period of six months the mortgagor will have no claim over the mortgaged property, and the mortgage deed will be deemed to be a deed of sale in favour of the mortgagee, cannot be sustained. It plainly takes away altogether, the mortgagors right to redeem the mortgage after the specified period. This is not permissible, for once a mortgage always a mortgage and therefore always redeemable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The clause extinguishes the right to redeem after the six-month period, violating the principle that once a mortgage always a mortgage and s.60 TPA which provides an unqualified right to redeem once arisen.

holdings.text: The term providing that the right to redeem arises only after 85 years does not constitute a clog on the equity of redemption.

anchor.surface_text: The term providing that the right to redeem will arise after eightyfive years does not, of course, take away the mortgagors right to redeem and is not, therefore, in that sense, a clog on the equity of redemption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The term merely postpones the accrual of the right to redeem until the principal becomes due as per contract, without taking it away entirely.

holdings.text: The 85-year mortgage term is not unconscionable or oppressive warranting equitable relief as there is no evidence of imposition, financial embarrassment, or unfair advantage taken by the mortgagee.

anchor.surface_text: We have no evidence in this case of the circumstances existing at the date of the mortgage as to the pecuniary condition of the mortgagor or as to anything else from which we may come to the conclusion that the mortgagee had taken advantage of the difficulties of the mortgagor and imposed a hard bargain on him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of mortgagor's necessity or oppression; prior mortgage redeemed favorably with smaller security; interest fair via usufruct; long terms common in India; suit delayed 47 years; all circumstances indicate reasonable bargain between equals.

holdings.text: The suit for redemption is premature because the principal money has not become due under the 85-year term and s.60 TPA allows redemption only after it becomes due.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 60 of that Act, at any time after the principal money has become due, the mortgagor has a right on payment or tender of the mortgage money to require the mortgagee to reconvey the mortgage property to him. The right conferred by this section has been called the right to redeem and the appellant sought to enforce this right by his suit. Under this section, however, that right can be exercised only after the mortgage money has become due.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.60 TPA conditions redemption right on principal becoming due; parties contractually fixed due date at 85 years, which is enforceable; no right accrues earlier.

holdings.text: The invalidity of the six-month forfeiture clause does not invalidate the 85-year term fixing when the principal becomes due.

anchor.surface_text: We wish to observe here that the learned advocate did not contend that the invalidity, as we have earlier held, of the term taking away the right to redeem the mortgage after the period of six months makes the term fixing the period of the mortgage at eighty five years invalid. This latter term stands quite apart.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The terms are independent; one fixes accrual of redemption right, the other attempts to extinguish it post-accrual; invalidity of latter does not affect former.

holdings.text: The mortgagee's right to enforce the mortgage and the mortgagor's right to redeem are co-extensive; no independent right for mortgagee to demand payment before due date.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the mortgage instrument permitting the mortgagee to demand any money, and it is well settled that the mortgagees right to enforce the mortgage and the mortgagors right to redeem are co-extensive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled law; no contractual provision allowing unilateral demand by mortgagee.

anchor.surface_text: Bakhtawai- Begum v. HusainiKhanam  1 , also the same view was expressed in these words Ordinarily, and in the absence of a special condition

precedents.cited_proposition: Ordinarily, and in the absence of a special condition entitling the mortgagor to redeem during the term for which the mortgage is created, the right of redemption can only arise on the expiration of the specified period.
precedents.cited_holding: the right of redemption can only arise on the expiration of the specified period.

anchor.surface_text: Lindley M. R. in Santley v. Wilde  1  in these words The principle is this a mortgage is a conveyance of land or an assignment of chattles as a security

precedents.cited_proposition: A mortgage is a conveyance of land or an assignment of chattels as a security for the payment of a debt or the discharge of some other obligation for which it is given. [...] Any provision inserted to prevent redemption [...] is what is meant by a clog or fetter on the equity of redemption and is therefore void. [...] once a mortgage always a mortgage.
precedents.cited_holding: Any provision inserted to prevent redemption on payment or performance of the debt or obligation for which the security was given is what is meant by a clog or fetter on the equity of redemption and is therefore void.

precedents.citation: Mohammad Sher Khan v. Seth Swami Dayal 2

anchor.surface_text: So it was said in Mohammad Sher Khan v. Seth Swami Dayal  2  An anomalous mortgage enabling a mortgagee after a lapse of time and in the absence of redemption to enter and take the rents in satisfaction of the interest.

precedents.case_name: Mohammad Sher Khan v Seth Swami Dayal
precedents.cited_proposition: Under s. 60 of the Transfer of Property Act, once the right to redeem has arisen it cannot be taken away.
precedents.cited_holding: The section is unqualified in its terms, and contains no saving provision as other sections do in favour of contracts to the contrary. [...] once the right to redeem has arisen it cannot be taken away.

anchor.surface_text: In a very early case, namely, Vermon v. Bethell Earl of Northington L. C. said, This court, as a court of conscience, is very jealous of persons taking securities for a loan, and converting such securities into purchases.

precedents.cited_proposition: Equity is jealous of persons taking securities for a loan and converting them into purchases; a mortgagee can never provide for any event or condition on which the equity of redemption shall be discharged.
precedents.cited_holding: a mortgagee can never provide at the time of making the loan for any event or condition on which the equity of redemption shall be discharged, and the conveyance absolute.

precedents.citation: G. and C. Kreglinger v. New Patagonia Meat and Cold Storage Company Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: Viscount Haldane L.C. repeated the same view when he said in G. and C. Kreglinger v. New Patagonia Meat and Cold Storage Company Ltd.  1  This jurisdiction was merely a special application of a more general power to relieve against penalties

precedents.case_name: G and C Kreglinger v New Patagonia Meat and Cold Storage Company Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: The equity jurisdiction against clogs originated to relieve against penalties in common law mortgages; it is limited to cases of unconscientious conduct, to ascertain the real nature of the transaction.
precedents.cited_holding: this was the origin of the jurisdiction [...] For the end to accomplish which the jurisdiction has been evolved ought to govern and limit its exercise by equity judges. [...] only where there was conduct which the Court of Chancery regarded as unconscientious that it interfered with freedom of contract.

Clog on Equity of Redemption support
Section 60 Transfer of Property Act support

outcome.relief_summary: Suit for redemption held premature as the 85-year mortgage term is valid and enforceable, and has not expired; suit must fail

edges.explanation: Argument a1 that suit is premature as principal not due until 85 years supports the holding h4 on same grounds.
Argument a1 claiming suit premature due to 85-year term and principal not due addresses issue i4.
a15 argues invalidity of 6-month clause does not make 85-year term invalid as they stand apart, attacking a2's bundling argument for clog

anchor.surface_text: One thing, therefore, is clear, namely, that the term in the mortgage contract, that on the failure of the mortgagor to redeem the mortgage within the specified period of six months the mortgagor will have no claim over the mortgaged property, and the mortgage deed will be deemed to be a deed of sale in favour of the mortgagee, cannot be sustained. It plainly takes away altogether, the mortgagors right to redeem the mortgage after the specified period. This is not permissible, for once a mortgage always a mortgage and therefore always redeemable.

One thing, therefore, is clear, namely, that the term in the mortgage contract, that on the failure of the mortgagor to redeem the mortgage within the specified period of six months the mortgagor will have no claim over the mortgaged property, and the mortgage deed will be deemed to be a deed of sale in favour of the mortgagee, cannot be sustained. It plainly takes away altogether, the mortgagors right to redeem the mortgage after the specified period. This is not permissible, for once a mortgage always a mortgage and therefore always redeemable.

anchor.surface_text: The term providing that the right to redeem will arise after eightyfive years does not, of course, take away the mortgagors right to redeem and is not, therefore, in that sense, a clog on the equity of redemption.

The term providing that the right to redeem will arise after eightyfive years does not, of course, take away the mortgagors right to redeem and is not, therefore, in that sense, a clog on the equity of redemption.

We have no evidence in this case of the circumstances existing at the date of the mortgage as to the pecuniary condition of the mortgagor or as to anything else from which we may come to the conclusion that the mortgagee had taken advantage of the difficulties of the mortgagor and imposed a hard bargain on him.

We have no evidence in this case of the circumstances existing at the date of the mortgage as to the pecuniary condition of the mortgagor or as to anything else from which we may come to the conclusion that the mortgagee had taken advantage of the difficulties of the mortgagor and imposed a hard bargain on him.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 60 of that Act, at any time after the principal money has become due, the mortgagor has a right on payment or tender of the mortgage money to require the mortgagee to reconvey the mortgage property to him. The right conferred by this section has been called the right to redeem and the appellant sought to enforce this right by his suit. Under this section, however, that right can be exercised only after the mortgage money has become due.

Under s. 60 of that Act, at any time after the principal money has become due, the mortgagor has a right on payment or tender of the mortgage money to require the mortgagee to reconvey the mortgage property to him. The right conferred by this section has been called the right to redeem and the appellant sought to enforce this right by his suit. Under this section, however, that right can be exercised only after the mortgage money has become due.

We wish to observe here that the learned advocate did not contend that the invalidity, as we have earlier held, of the term taking away the right to redeem the mortgage after the period of six months makes the term fixing the period of the mortgage at eighty five years invalid. This latter term stands quite apart.

There is nothing in the mortgage instrument permitting the mortgagee to demand any money, and it is well settled that the mortgagees right to enforce the mortgage and the mortgagors right to redeem are co-extensive.
